The National Senatorial Campaign Committee has pledged to pull the $5 million it had planned to spend in Missouri if Akin stays in the race, a Republican with knowledge of the committee’s activity confirmed to RealClearPolitics. Message.Title: Otellini Calls Out Wall Street ANAlysts
Message.Msg: Isn't it about time to stop the market manipulation by high frequency computer trading which governs 70% of INTC's shares traded? Pure and simple it is nothing but market manipulation that transfers wealth from INTC's shareholders to the Wall Street robbers. One week these programs run INTC shares up and they sell call options, the next week it is down. In sum, despite earnings doubling over the past five years, INTC's share price is basically unchanged. Not just INTC's shares are being manipulated, but many other mature tech stocks: AMAT, NVLS, KLAC, STX, WDC, etc. Since 2010, STX earnings are up 120%, yet despite the recent rise share STX' price is up just 25% Isn't it about time to put an end to this scam? Paul Otellini in a recent Business Week interview stated that certain Analysts may be pursuing an agenda that derives trading profits for their firms rather than reporting the facts: Business Week: "You guys have been churning out record revenue pretty regularly. But people aren’t paying as much attention to your strengths, like high-end chips that go into data centers. Critics are more fixated on, “Gosh, Intel missed this whole smartphone surge.” Is that fair?" Otellini: "We’ve had a very good last few years. Part of it is that the analyst community has their own agenda. They may be long on something and short on something else. We tend not to worry about that." http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-08-09/paul-otellini-on-intel-and-the-pcs-evolution#p2

Topic.Title: Otellini Calls Out Wall Street ANAlysts

Message.Msg: Otellini: "We’ve had a very good last few years. Part of it is that the analyst community has their own agenda. They may be long on something and short on something else. We tend not to worry about that." We tend not to worry about that!?! That's your number 1 priority as CEO: raise shareholder wealth. Very disturbing. As I've said many times before, Paul O. has to go & a real leader who will raise the share price by any means necessary needs to be his replacement.

Topic.Title: Otellini Calls Out Wall Street ANAlysts

Message.Msg: If you want it on stronger terms, here is what STX's CEO, an ex Bear Stearns banker" said about how traders and investment bank Analysts scam the share prices of mature trech stocks, stealing shareholder wealth away: "Drive stocks are being priced by the large investment banks for trading volume, and volume requires volatility. So that's why all the big firms are in a different camp than the smaller research firms on their perspective of the drive industry... It is because the big banks are motivated by volatility and the boutique firms aren't... and the research of the big firms reflects doubts. So they create environment that always creates doubt. Why does that work? Because you have traders who love to make that work" Stephen Luczo, Forbes Inteview 4/12/12

Topic.Title: Otellini Calls Out Wall Street ANAlysts

The CEO of FB raised share price "by any means necessary". His benefit is leaking away too. Just because you say something "many times before" does not make it any more right than the first time. You have your opinion. I disagree with your assumptions and opinion and think it is misguided. The tech industry is at an inflection point where form factor and usage is changing dramatically. Intel execs can spend their time yelling at analysts or they can spend the time repositioning Intel to be strong in the face of change. Perception is changed slowly and VERY SLOWLY for those who have a vested interest in the other side winning.

Topic.Title: Otellini Calls Out Wall Street ANAlysts

Message.Msg: I have seen trading behavior that I cannot explain with my understanding of how all the interrelated markets work. I have also seen many general complaints about manipulative trading practices. When I ask about them, I am told to "go google it". I ask about it because I have not been able to figure it out AND I am not confident that anyone else has either. I would be intrested in an explanation of how the manipulation occurs and how it affects share price if you ever see a specific example. My problem is that most if not all of the manipulation has been explained by vague theory presented as fact. I have shared my dividend arbitraging theory and pointed out what I suspect. IMO, Intel has become a victim of its own success and inability to diversify outside the computer industry. Once they own 90% of the market, they ARE the market and cannot grow revenue or profits faster than that market. It is tough risking the cash cow for new markets.

"INtel will be competing with a common CPU ISA, that the entire world's R&D will be supporting..." So, you are saying the entire world's R&D will supporting ARM64? It's more like R&D from around the world will be supporting it. There is a niche market that this core would fit into. There are open source web hosts for example who may be interested in ARM64. This isn't pandora's box however for ARM. Intel has had a long history of having server processors show up in the market from competition and then having to respond to them. AMD has pulled fast ones now and then. ARM64 has been broadcast years in advance. They are competing on parameters that Intel is already addressing such as low power consumption. My question is what node will ARM64 be at, realistically? 28nm? Or the mythical 20nm? I am thinking by the end of 2013/2014 ARM64 20nm may not be readily available. What you will have in the streets is ARM64 28nm vs. Intel at 14nm. R&D means nothing if you can't get product on the streets. Tic Toc will soften the blow of ARM64. I expect many great news articles about ARM64, and the stock price to surge with the news of the 'x86 killer server processor' as it will be explained to naive ARMH investors. But, as for a swift acceptance of ARM64, what will drive it?

"Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company's (TSMC) 28nm processes have topped a yield rate of 80%, the Chinese-language Commercial Times cited unnamed equipment suppliers as saying in a recent report. Meanwhile, the foundry's new 12-inch fab - Fab 15 - will have a capacity of more than 100,000 12-inch equivalent wafers in the fourth quarter of 2012, according to the report." Read it carefully, it means that one one wafer they got a yield of 80%. If they could consistently do this they would put it in writing. What's their real yield rate? 40%. If they had a yield rate above 50% they would switch immediately to selling by the wafer? Why? As yields improve costs would go down, and a consistent price would drive the market. What I am reading from this article is that the pay per wafer business plan isn't working and they are having guys like D.A.N out their BSing suppliers with bogus numbers. As the numbers on the bottom of the article state the sales figures aren't that great, 5 and 7 percent versus the expected 20%. This pay per wafer idea was the best thing ever for Intel. They easily lost 6 months due to production issues and now pure stupidity. The iPhone 5 threat of TSMC/QCOM is now gone. The iPhone 5 will most likely be a Samsung 32nm. And with the full scale production cycle of the holiday season now out of reach, they are ramping up production for the slowest time of the year for consumer gadet sales. Oh well, at least they will be ready for ARM64 by the end of next year.
That makes two of us.

There is a niche market that this core would fit into. There are open source web hosts for example who may be interested in ARM64. This isn't pandora's box however for ARM. ----- I'm not sure you get it? This isn't one core from ARMH. Applied Micro, Cavium Networks, Qualcomm, Samsung and Nvidia will be designing their own CPU's to the ARMv8 ISA. Each of these CPU's will have a different power/performance/price ratios. ----- My question is what node will ARM64 be at, realistically? 28nm? Or the mythical 20nm? I am thinking by the end of 2013/2014 ARM64 20nm may not be readily available. What you will have in the streets is ARM64 28nm vs. Intel at 14nm. ----- ARMH's own CPU's meeting the ARMv8 ISA are targeting the 20nm node. Others, such as Applied Micro are looking at 40nm then moving to 28nm. ----- R&D means nothing if you can't get product on the streets. Tic Toc will soften the blow of ARM64. I expect many great news articles about ARM64, and the stock price to surge with the news of the 'x86 killer server processor' as it will be explained to naive ARMH investors. But, as for a swift acceptance of ARM64, what will drive it? ----- There will be no ARM ISA based 'x86 killer server processor'. There will be lots of *different* SoC implementations targeting various sections of the market.

Message.Title: History-
Message.Msg: $26 TOOOOOOOO FUNNNNNNNNNNNNNNY!

Once and for all I get that ARMH makes the specs that companies like Nvidia license for ARM. I also get that the ARM CPU is inside the SoC's such as the Tegra3 and A5X. What I am picking up from the various engineering types on the board is an unsophisticated view of how the markets work. When I ask "what will push this technology" this is what I mean. The sales numbers for server processors don't drive themselves. Intel has territory sales managers calling on various geographical locations. Most often they have EE degrees and are paid well. They get to know the players in their territory. When a company has 100 or more servers they keep in contact with them. The large accounts like Google for example have their best reps working for them in key account positions. They may even have dedicated staff on site at Google's various server farms. The problem you'll have with an ARM64 processor is that Intel is very well entrenched in the market. They have an uphill battle like they won't believe. This is a market Intel knows well and has feet on the street willing to fight for every last sale. I can understand the fringe sales for the smaller and more obscure players. But if you are expecting an overnight explosion like smartphone sales, won't happen. Like Intel has said before it's 10 to 15% of the market, max. An organic growth rate is more likely, but it will take years.

Message.Title: TSMC 28nm yields still behind the curvec
Message.Msg: July 12, 2012 -- Barclays Capital is seeing various reasons for a Q3 2012 semiconductor fab order/shipment pull-back, following meetings around SEMICON West 2012 this week. Barclays expects that TSMC’s pushout of its Fab 14 phase 2 caused Applied Materials to lower its revenue forecast for front-end semiconductor tools. Despite well-known shortages at 28nm for Qualcomm (QCOM), Nvidia (NVDA), AMD, and other chip suppliers, TSMC is likely hesitant to add capacity until it improves its 28nm high-k metal gate (HKMG) yields. Barclays interprets this situation as leaving lithography and process control orders intact, while more capacity driven players would see a delay. Other factors in the Q3 lull include a retrofit at Samsung’s Austin fab and a modest pushout at Fab 16.

Message.Title: Sell INTC, Buy Apple?
Message.Msg: Both stocks trade at a P/E around 12 but Apple would appear to have more upside potential from current levels considering it's growth prospects. Intel has a better dividend yield and in my opinion is more undervalued than Apple but it certainly is not as "sexy" as Apple. Due to it's popularity I could see Apple getting to $750 before Intel gets to $30. Thoughts? Disclosure: I am long INTC and don't care for Apple although I applaud their marketing expertise. They have successfully convinced people that they "need" their products versus "wanting" them.

Weak....But true. Dell is supposedly 1 of the RT vendors & not a peep out of them on the call tonite about this garbage product. I wonder why?? BTW, the people I know who have tested NT "products" said they wouldnt even use them if they were given to them for free. Cant wait for the October reviews to roll-out...

Topic.Title: Otellini Calls Out Wall Street ANAlysts

Message.Msg: <Business Week: "You guys have been churning out record revenue pretty regularly. But people aren’t paying as much attention to your strengths, like high-end chips that go into data centers. Critics are more fixated on, “Gosh, Intel missed this whole smartphone surge.” Is that fair?" Otellini: "We’ve had a very good last few years. Part of it is that the analyst community has their own agenda. They may be long on something and short on something else. We tend not to worry about that."> On a Q&A sesion on a recent presentation (I think an analyst meeting), Ottelini kept getting the same question over and over as though these dorks didn't really understand the business. Finally, Ottelini said, "I'm not going to talk to you guys anymore." I've been looking all over for that bit, but I can't find it. Since then I haven't seen any Intel generated commentary or exciting announcements. The IDF is coming up in about three weeks. If there is something important for developers to know, Intel should be starting to talk soon. You can't just pop a bunch of new stuff on your developers the first day of the meeting. The above interview kind of confirms that Ottelini is doing a slow burn over the apparent ignorance of the analyst community. Sooner or later there will be a huge piece of news that will catch 150 million short shares in somthing of a "hurry" to buy. Payback is a tough deal. Just to repeat...the IDF is Sep 11-13. Ottelini has always given the opening keynote speech. Not this year. The Apple iPhone 5 intro is Sep 12. Will Ottelini be there instead of the IDF?
